channel.title: Investopedia Term of the Day
channel.description: A new term every day, plus the 10 most recent terms.

item.title: Pivot Point
item.description: A technical analysis indicator used to determine the overall trend of the market over different time frames.

item.title: LIBOR-in-Arrears Swap
item.description: A swap in which the interest paid on a particular date is determined by that date's interest rate rather than the interest rate of the previous payment date.

item.title: Equity Premium Puzzle - EPP
item.description: An phenomenon that describes the anomalously higher historical real returns of stocks over government bonds.

item.title: Money Manager
item.description: A business or bank responsible for managing the securities portfolio of an individual or institutional investor.

item.title: At-The-Close Order
item.description: An order specifying that a trade is to be executed at the close of the market, or as near to the closing price as possible.

item.title: BRL (Brazilian Real)
item.description: The currency abbreviation symbol for the Brazilian real (BRL), the currency for Brazil. The Brazilian real is made up of 100 centavos and is often presented with the symbol R$.

item.title: Sacred Cow
item.description: A firmly held mainstream belief that is considered to be true without independent verification. In finance, and in particular in investing, there are many sacred cows that are thought to be true, but are difficult to prove scientifically.

item.title: George Soros
item.description: A famous hedge fund manager who is widely considered to be one of the world's greatest investors.

item.title: Ginzy Trading
item.description: Ginzy trading was originally performed primarily to achieve an average price for the customer which is within the predefined increments, or "ticks," in which the market is traded.

item.title: Double-Spending
item.description: The risk that a digital currency can be spent twice. Double-spending is a problem unique to digital currencies because digital information can be reproduced relatively easily.

item.title: Eat Your Own Dog Food
item.description: The basic premise behind "eating your own dog food" is that if a firm expects paying customers to use its products or services, it should expect no less from its own employees.

item.title: Tertiary Industry
item.description: The segment of the economy that provides services to its consumers. This includes a wide range of businesses including financial institutions, schools, transports and restaurants.

item.title: Postnuptial Agreement
item.description: A contract created by spouses after entering into marriage that outlines the ownership of financial assets in the event of a divorce.

item.title: Yupcap
item.description: Yupcaps are people in their late twenties or early thirties with post secondary educations and well-paying jobs who are unable to purchase property due to factors such as...

item.title: Saber Currency
item.description: A proposed Brazilian currency that would be handed out by the Ministry of Education to 7-year-olds to be redeemed only for university tuition.

item.title: Retirement Readiness
item.description: Retirement readiness typically refers to being financially prepared for retirement, or the degree to which an individual is on target to meet his or her retirement-income goals so that the standard of living enjoyed while working will be maintained after retirement.

item.title: Game Changer
item.description: 1. A person who is a visionary. - OR - 2. A company that alters its business strategy and conceives an entirely new business plan.

item.title: Graded Vesting
item.description: The process by which employees gain a certain percentage of irrevocable rights over employer contributions made to the employee's retirement plan account each year until the employee is fully vested.

item.title: Empire Building
item.description: The act of attempting to increase the size and scope of an individual or organization's power and influence.

item.title: Nonfeasance
item.description: Failing to execute or perform an act or duty required by position/office or law that results in harm or damage to a person or property.
